The  proposed  Development  Policy  Support  Program  (DPSP) 
embedded  in  the  Government’s  Medium  Term  Development  Plan 
(RPJM) for 2004-2009. It supports the RPJM’s broad goal of stimulating 
higher and sustainable economic growth (to 7% average annual growth 
by 2009 up from levels around 4% prior to 2004) and halving poverty (to 
8.2% by 2009 from 16.6% in 2004). To achieve these goals, the DPSP 
is  a  policy  engagement  tool  that  accelerates  economy-wide  and  cross 
cutting reforms.  More specifically, it has involved the implementation of 
a set of policy actions in four core areas to (i) improve macroeconomic 
stability  and  creditworthiness;  (ii)  promote  investments;  (iii)  strengthen 
the  financial  sector;  and  (iv)  enhance  the  quality  of  public  financial 
management and reduce corruption. Supported by a $200 million single 
tranche  operation,  the  DPSP’s  key  achievements  are  the  upfront 
implementation  of  the  core  policy  actions,  and  the  development  and 
building  of  full  Government  commitment  for  a  forward-looking  program 
that deepens the reforms in the core areas, while striving to strengthen 
public service delivery to the poor.  
 
Exiting  the  International  Monetary  Fund-supported  program,  to  ensure 
policy  continuity  and  to  deepen  the  post-crisis  reforms,  in  a  period  of 
political transition leading up to the Presidential elections, in September 
2003  the  Government  announced  a  structural  reform  package  -  the 
White  Paper.  Recognizing  the  centrality  of  this  Paper,  the  principal 
development partners, including ADB, supported its formulation as well 
as  implementation.  ADB  specifically  focused  on  deepening  reforms  in 
finance  and  governance,  building  on  post-crisis  sector  restructuring 
outcomes.  Substantial  ADB  technical  assistance  and  economic  and 
sector  work  supported  White  Paper  implementation.  In  parallel,  the 
World  Bank  supported  White  Paper  implementation  over  the  period 
2003–2004  with  a  Development  Policy  Loan  (DPL)  (cofinanced  by  the 
Government of Japan).  The DPL framework has its origin in the World 
Bank’s  Country  Assistance  Strategy,  which  advocates  support  for  the 
Government’s  macroeconomic  and  crosscutting  reforms  through  three 
sequentially designed DPLs.  
 
Building on the White Paper and developing its own priorities, the new 
Government,  which  assumed  office  in  October  2004,  announced  the 
RPJM  for  2004–2009  in  November  2005.  The  RPJM  has  three 
objectives:  peace  and  security,  justice  and  democracy,  and  prosperity

The DPSP aims to harmonize policy reform support of key development 
partners  by  providing  parallel  financing  with  the  World  Bank  and  the 
Government  of  Japan,  which  are  processing  a  second  phase  of  the 
Development Policy Loan (DPL-2). The DPSP effectively builds on and 
deepens  sector-specific  reforms  supported  by  ADB  through  past  and 
ongoing operations. 
 
The DPSP adheres to ADB’s recent efforts to reduce transaction costs 
for  its  developing  member  countries.  The  approach  is  also  consistent 
with  ADB’s  reform  agenda,  as  outlined  in  the  Long-Term  Strategic 
Framework,  Medium-Term  Strategy,  and  the  Middle-Income  Country 
Initiative. The DPSP helps implement and fulfill ADB’s obligations to the 
Rome  Declaration  on  harmonizing  procedures  of  multilateral 
development  banks  (February  2003)  and  the  recent  Paris  Declaration 
on Aid Effectiveness (March 2005).   
 
The  DPSP  aims  to  (i)  achieve  and  sustain  higher  economic  growth 
through  improved  fiscal  management  and  investment  climate,  and 
enhancing  financial  sector  soundness;  and  (ii)  reduce  poverty  and 
unemployment  by  reorienting  public  expenditures  to  productive  needs, 
and by strengthening governance in public financial management. 
 
The  Government’s  external  financing  needs  for  the  2005  budget  are 
estimated at $3.6 billion, comprising $1.25 billion in program loans – to 
support  the  reforms  –  and  $2.35  billion  in  project  disbursements.  In 
addition  to  the  DPSP  support  of  $200  million,  the  Government  has 
requested $400 million from the World Bank through DPL-2 and parallel 
financing  support  (amount  to  be  determined)  from  the  Government  of 
Japan.

The DPSP  and ADB’s  Strategy. The DPSP is a key pillar of ADB’s emerging country 
strategy and program for 2006–2010. Under this, a dual-track approach is proposed to ensure 
continuity  and  sustainability  of  past  ADB-supported  initiatives.  This  would  involve  structuring 
ADB support through (i) participation in the DPLs to strengthen the macroeconomic and fiscal 
framework and address cross-cutting concerns; and (ii) sector-specific policy interventions. For 
example, in 2005, ADB launched upfront partnerships with the World Bank and the Government 
of Japan to develop a conceptual framework and design for infrastructure sector reform. All key 
development partners have a policy engagement in areas covered in the ADB-supported Local 
Government  Finance  and  Governance  Reform  Sector  Development  Program,3  which  provides 
an overall umbrella for decentralization policy reforms. Joint technical work is underway by both 
the ADB and the World Bank on poverty reduction and acceleration of MDGs.  
 
8. 
The proposed ADB parallel financing support for the DPL (through the DPSP) and ADB-
supported and coordinated sector-specific interventions are among the key holistic attempts to 
align  and  harmonize  development  partner  strategies  with  Indonesia’s  country  strategy  and 
priorities.  ADB’s  participation  in  the  DPL  process  and  the  parallel  policy  dialogue  on  sector 
reforms has been appreciated by Government. Over the medium-term, the dual-track approach 
will  help  reinforce  reforms  under  both  streams  and  facilitate  close  coordination  among 
development partners.

Harmonization  and  Complementarity.  The  policy  components  and  actions  of  the 
DPSP are sequenced and paced to accommodate the prevailing political economy of Indonesia, 
where the legislature must fully buy into the agenda, where it takes time to ensure stakeholder 
ownership  and  effective  implementation.  Harmonization  of  strategies  of  development  partners 
around the Government’s own program has bolstered further country ownership of the reforms 
and has helped forge a new relationship between the Government and its principal development 
partners.  Further,  harmonization  around  the  reform  programs,  such  as  the  DPLs  and  ADB-
supported  sector  reform  initiatives,  builds  on  the  natural  synergy  and  complementarities  that 
exist  among  the  development  partners.  Combining  the  strengths  and  expertise  of  each  of  the 
development  partners  has  helped  ensure  quality  and  consistency  of  advice  and  reduce  the 
transaction cost of policy dialogue.

11. 
Indonesia’s track record of economic management in recent years has been consistent 
and  positive.  During  2001–2004,  real  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  grew  steadily  and  fiscal 
consolidation  was  impressive,  with  the  budget  deficit  declining  from  minus  3.2%  of  GDP  to 
minus  1.1%,  a  reduction  of  about  2.1%.  Effective  monetary  management  stabilized  inflation, 
interest rates, and the exchange rate (around Rp9,500); and foreign exchange reserves rose to 
about  $35  billion.  The  real  GDP  in  the  first  half  of  2005  grew  by  5.9%  driven  by  strong 
investment growth,5 reversing the earlier consumption-led growth pattern, as reflected in the rise 
in  import  of  capital  goods  and  accelerating  growth  in  the  nontradable  sectors.  Despite  strong 
export growth, the rise in imports due to adverse developments in the oil and gas sector led to a 
rise  in  the  external  current  account  deficit.  The  combination  of  these  events  resulted  in  a 
cumulative drawdown of foreign exchange reserves by nearly $6 billion in the past few months, 
to $32 billion in September 2005.

15.  While the Government has embarked on a program of bold reforms, the reforms are far 
from  being  complete.  The  unfinished  reform  agenda  has  provided  the  opportunity  for  the 
development partners to lend support through a series of forward-looking interventions targeting 
specific areas. 
 
16.  Macroeconomic  and  Fiscal  Policies.  Stringent  fiscal  policy  has  helped  reduce  the 
budget deficit but has squeezed development spending, which sharply declined after the onset 
of the crisis and stagnated at 2–3% of GDP during 1998–2005, as compared with 7–8% prior to 
1997. Over the same period, recurrent expenditures declined from about 12% of GDP to about 
9%.  In  2004,  public  expenditures  came  under  renewed  pressures  as  the  fuel  subsidies 
increased to 3.5% of GDP, leaving less than Rp80 trillion for development expenditures. Despite 
being an oil-producing country, Indonesia has not been able to reap any significant gains from 
the  favorable  global  oil  market  environment  due  to  lack  of  investments  in  oil  exploration  and 
development. 
  
17. 
In proportional terms, the approved 2005 budget allocations present a similar picture to 
that  of  2004,  with  revised  fuel  subsidies  estimated  at  about  Rp89.5  trillion,  leaving  limited 
resources  for  development  needs.  Nonetheless,  the  recent  reduction  in  fuel  subsidies  has 
provided  the  Government  with  significant  scope  to  reorient  public  expenditures  to  achieve  the 
Government’s dual goal of accelerated economic growth and poverty reduction.

19. 
Debt  Management.  The  Government  has  managed  to  gradually  decrease  the  level  of 
debt over the last few years, from 91% of GDP in 2000 to 52% by mid-2005. The overall debt is 
projected to decline to about 30% of GDP by 2010. Debt sustainability analysis, undertaken by 
the World Bank and IMF, indicate that both external and domestic public debt is fairly robust to 
shocks  in  exchange  rates,  interest  rates,  and  GDP  trends.  However,  considering  that  slightly 
more than half of the outstanding debt, or about $66 billion, is denominated in foreign currency, 
long-term,  and  owed  to  noncommercial  lenders,  one  of  the  main  risks  facing  Indonesia  is 
exchange rate risk. Recent trends in interest rates and the move to issue sovereign bonds are 
to  eventually  magnify  interest  rate  risks.  The  Government  needs  to  adopt  a  clear  strategy  to 
manage such risk as it pursues its strategy to gradually reduce overall debt. 
 
20. 
Investment  Constraints.  After  years  of  declining  investments,  signs  of  recovery  are 
evident, although continued low investments remain a concern. The weak legal and regulatory 
framework  for  investment,  problems  of  interpretation  and  application  of  the  law  and 
enforceability  of  contractual  obligations  have  led  to  high-profile  and  high-value  investment 
disputes, some of them concluded in favor of vested interests and involving bankruptcy litigation 
against  well-known  companies  with  foreign  shareholding.  The  approval  process  for  foreign 
investments  by  the  Investment  Coordinating  Board  is  protracted.  Indonesia  lags  other  Asian 
countries in this area: it takes 80–151 days on average to register and establish a locally owned 
limited liability company in Indonesia, compared to 56 days in Viet Nam, 41 days in the People's 
Republic  of  China,  and  30  days  in  Malaysia.  Nontransparent  processes  leave  scope  for 
discretion in verification and approval of investment applications, and corruption.10
 
21. 
Infrastructure  Development.  While  infrastructure  investments  in  Indonesia  exceeded 
5% of GDP prior to the financial crisis, they have subsequently fallen and not recovered beyond 
2-3% of GDP. Public service provision and coverage are low across all sectors, but particularly 
low in telecommunications, roads, power, and water supply and sanitation, and in areas outside 
Java,  resulting  in  widening  economic  and  social  disparities.  The  Government  estimates  the 
infrastructure investment requirements at around $145 billion for 2005–2009. It further estimates 
that  only  17%  can  be  financed  from  the  national  budget,  and  7%  by  official  development 
assistance, which will be largely used for promoting public-private partnerships. This means that 
the bulk of the requirements will have to be met by private capital. The infrastructure financing 
constraints are aggravated by the lack of depth and diversification in the financial system, which 
does not provide long-term capital.  
 
22. 
Investors  are  concerned  about  the  policy,  legal,  and  regulatory  distortions  in  the 
infrastructure  sectors,  and  face  country  risks  as  recourse  to  the  judicial  system  is  weak. 
Although a number of projects that halted after the crisis have been renegotiated, gaps in sector 
policies  and  recent  adverse  outcomes,  such  as  the  annulment  of  the  Electricity  Law  by  the 
Constitutional  Court  in  December  2004  have  negatively  affected  investor  confidence.  Lack  of 
strong  coordination  across  sector  ministries  also  adversely  affects  infrastructure  investment. 
The  National  Committee  for  the  Acceleration  of  Infrastructure  Development  (KKPPI)  has  been 
established  and  strengthened  through  a  Presidential  Decree  in  2005,  but  it  needs  strong 
technical and administrative support to function as an effective coordination mechanism. Due to 
the  legal  and  country  risks,  the  Government  needs  to  adopt  a  risk-sharing  mechanism  to 
mitigate  against  the  legal  and  regulatory  uncertainties  faced  by  investors.  Transaction  quality 
needs to be ensured by thorough project preparation and transparent bidding process. There is 
a  need  for an  effective  mechanism  for  an  independent  and  impartial  review,  roles  that  can  be 
played only by a strong KKPPI.

23. 
Financial  Sector.  Indonesia’s  financial  sector  has  stabilized  but  continues  to  exhibit 
structural  vulnerabilities  and  risks.  The  financial  performance  of  Indonesia’s  banks  is 
comparable  or  better  than  other  developing  countries  in  the  region  and  gross  nonperforming 
loan ratios have declined over time from above 12% in 2001 to 7% by mid-2005, although some 
large  state-owned  commercial  banks  continue  to  carry  large  nonperforming  loans.  Financial 
intermediation is increasing, although its growth is impacted by upward pressure on interest rate 
and credit and operational risks in the system. Banks have as yet not fully adopted sound risk 
management systems. Recent scandals in some banks—including large state-owned banks as 
well as smaller, reasonably well-managed private banks—manifest weak corporate and financial 
governance  practices.  Lack  of  an  effective  financial  safety  net  and  liquidity  support  for  the 
banking system pose a systemic risk to the system.11 Nonbank financial institutions (NBFIs) still 
account  for  a  relatively  low  16%  of  total  financial  assets.  While  the  Indonesian  capital  market 
has been the best performing in the region and equity market capitalization registered triple-fold 
growth in recent years, issues of breadth and depth of the market and enforcement of regulation 
and supervision remain a concern. The long-term debt market has been constrained by delays 
in  pension  and  insurance  sector  reforms.  The  financial  sector  lacks  innovation,  both  at  the 
institution and product level. Much of the liquidity is locked up in Government bonds.  
  
24. 
Financial  Management  and  Anticorruption.  The  key  concerns  in  public  financial 
management  are  (i)  an  outdated  legal  environment;  (ii)  an  opaque  and  inefficient  budget 
formulation process, and the separation of recurrent and development budgets; (iii) an inefficient 
payments  system  and  weak  monitoring  arrangements;  (iv)  fragmented  cash  management 
arrangements;  (v)  unreliable  accounting,  auditing,  and  reporting  systems;  and  (vii)  overlaps 
between external and internal audit agencies, reflecting unclear roles and responsibilities. Public 
and  investor  perception  surveys  (such  as  those  by  Transparency  International)  indicate  that 
corruption is evident at all levels in the public sector. Legal and regulatory uncertainty in most 
sectors  acts  as  a  major  impediment  to  good  governance.  Public  procurement  remains  a 
challenging  area  of  reform;  malpractices  here  have  impeded  development  spending.  The 
President  has  made  corruption  eradication  a  top  priority,  and  the  establishment  of  the 
Corruption  Eradication  Commission  (KPK)  has  brought  new  hope.  Persistence  in  the 
Government’s anticorruption efforts and sound enforcement will be vital to reducing corruption in 
public life.

27.  Many multiyear and multitranche operations have had implementation difficulties, in part 
because  ambitious,  multiyear  reform  agendas  were  in  excess  of  the  institutional  capacity  and 
political economy of the country. For example, the adjustment lending experience of the World 
Bank indicates that during 1990-1999, 39% of two-tranche operations and 63% of three-tranche 
operations had waivers or cancellations.13 ADB experience has been similar. As a result, as an 
alternative,  the  World  Bank  has  now  moved  increasingly  to  a  series  of  single-tranche 
operations, with a well-defined, medium-term (programmatic) framework specified at the outset, 
including completed up-front reform actions and triggers for subsequent operations. The DPLs 
fit into this mold.

estimates suggest they could result in a tax revenue loss of up to 0.5% of GDP. However, the

Impact of Improved Debt Management. The Government’s debt management strategy 
is yielding results. Overall public debt has fallen from 91% of GDP in 2000 to 59% in 2003, and 
to 52% by June 2005. During 2000–2005, the outstanding domestic debt declined from 47% of 
GDP  to  25%,  and  external  debt  from  44%  to  27%.  Public  sector  debt  has  been  reprofiled, 
effectively  resulting  in  the  amount  of  commercial  debt  being  managed  comprising  2–3%  of 
overall external debt. Maturities have been lengthened with average time to maturity increasing 
from  5.9  years  in  2000  to  7.4  years  in  June  2005.  Sound  fiscal  and  macroeconomic 
management has allowed Indonesia to expand its access to domestic, and reenter international, 
debt markets. However, while debt-service costs have declined to 6% of GDP, they still account 
for  53%  of  the  non-oil  revenues  and  42%  of  primary  spending.  Given  the  relatively  high  debt-
service burden and the exchange rate and interest rate vulnerabilities, Indonesia has committed 
to gradually reducing its debt level. The Government’s medium-term target is to reduce its public 
debt to 30% of GDP by 2010, although debt-threshold assessments indicate a debt level in the 
range  of  35–42%  of  GDP  would  be  appropriate  (Appendix  6).  The  Government's  approach  to 
gradual  debt  reduction  will  release  additional  resources  for  public  expenditure  and  poverty 
reduction programs. In quantitative terms, the Government's current strategy would reduce the 
debt stock by about $11 billion–$16 billion annually through 2006–2010, which could provide a 
significant expenditure cushion.

executive branch implementation and political capacity. The high ownership has already helped 
development of the future direction of reform and adjustments in areas where it was warranted. 
Together this has provided for sustainability of reforms, while reducing the transaction costs for

This  year  has  been  a  good  one  for  growth  in  Indonesia.  In  the  first  half  of  2005  GDP  growth

Macroeconomic  stability  continues  to  underlie  our  basic  strategy  and  we  intend  to  focus  on

national  borrowing  framework,  a  better  institutional  design  to  assess  and  set  fiscal  policy  and

Inflation has been on the rise this year due, in part to the run up in the exchange rate and, in part, 
to fuel price increases. With the latest increase in fuel prices inflation will rise further and now 
represents  a  potential  challenge  to  macroeconomic  stability  and  poverty  reduction.  Bank

year’s budget in addition to continuing the cash transfers we are budgeting substantial increases 
for the social sectors (schools, health clinics), and small scale and rural infrastructure (especially 
roads). In fact the sum of these programs will reach 60 percent of the funds reallocated from the 
subsidy reduction. Nevertheless we remain mindful that the recent run-up in world oil prices and 
fixed  domestic  prices  jeopardized  our  fiscal  position,  economic  efficiency  and  needed  energy

regulation (Perpres 55/2005) that raised fuel prices on October 3, also signals the government’s 
intent to continue to reallocate untargeted subsidies and to a continuing adjustment of domestic 
prices to market ones.

This note provides the IMF staff's current assessment of Indonesia's macroeconomic conditions and outlook 
for  the  coming  period,  ahead  of  the  staff’s  next  Post-Program  Monitoring  mission  to  Jakarta  in  early 
December. 
  
Economic Conditions and Outlook 

•  Following a period of increased volatility in August and September, Indonesia’s financial markets have 
stabilized following action taken by the authorities to address the underlying imbalances in September 
and  October.  Monetary  policy  has  been  tightened  significantly  and  the  government  announced 
sharp cuts in domestic fuel subsidies, effective October 1, to address pressures on the budget and 
the balance of payments associated with high international prices. Breaking a policy of gradual and 
modest rate increases, BI raised its one-month policy rate by 125 basis points to 10 percent in late 
August/early September and by an additional 100 basis points in early October. The last hike came 
after the sharp increases on October 1 in domestic fuel prices—88 percent on gasoline, 200 percent 
on  kerosene,  and  185  percent  on  diesel.  The  fuel  price  increase  was  accompanied  by  a 
compensation package, whereby 15½ million families will receive about US$120 annually to help 
offset the impact of rising fuel costs on their income. Markets have reacted positively to the interest 
rate and domestic fuel price increases, and both the rupiah and the stock market have strengthened 
since.  

•  The  macroeconomic  situation  is  weaker  but  the  outlook  for  growth  is  still  favorable.  Real  GDP 
grew  by  5.1  percent  in  2004  and  is  envisaged  to  increase  by  5–5½  percent  in  2005.  This  pace  is 
somewhat  slower  than  the  6  percent  growth  registered  earlier  this  year,  reflecting  the  impact  of  the 
recent  financial  market  volatility  on  consumer  and  investment  spending,  as  well  as  higher  oil  prices. 
Inflation is expected to remain in the double digits in the near-term, following the big jump in October 
to 18 percent (year-on-year) that largely reflected the impact of domestic fuel price increases but also a 
more  general  pickup  in  price  pressures.    To  contain  underlying  inflation,  BI  raised  its  policy  interest 
rate by another 125 basis points on November 1, and stated its commitment to take further action, as 
needed, so as to bring inflation back down to single digits by the end of 2006.   

•  Fiscal policy remains prudent and the revised 2005 budget deficit target of about one percent of 
GDP  is  achievable.  The  revised  2005  budget  approved  by  parliament  in  September  entailed  a  slight 
increase in the deficit target by 0.1 percent of GDP to 0.9 percent of GDP (1.3 percent of GDP under 
IMF  definitions).  With  fuel  subsidy  payments  this  year  now  expected  to  reach  just  over  3 percent  of 
GDP,  compared  with  over  4  percent  estimated  prior  to  the  hike  and  given  the  slower-than-expected 
pace of capital expenditures so far, the deficit target should be met. The 2006 revised budget, reflecting 
more  updated  macroeconomic  developments,  including  the  cut  in  domestic  fuel  subsidies,  was  just 
approved  by  Parliament.  The  deficit  target  has  been  kept  at  0.7  percent  of  GDP  in  line  with  the 
authorities  commitment  of  continued  fiscal  consolidation  and  a  further  reduction  in  the  public  debt 
burden. 

•  The  international  reserve  position  is  expected  to  recover  again  over  the  medium  term.  Gross 
international  reserves,  although  adequate  in  terms  of  short-term  debt  at  about  130  percent  of  GDP,

•  The  overall  performance  of  the  banking  sector  has  improved,  but  risks  remain.  In  recent  years, 
banks were able to improve earnings as net interest margins improved due to lower interest rates. Asset 
quality has also improved at several banks, although some banks recently showed higher NPLs due to 
stricter classification rules enforced by BI. Going forward, rising interest rates will increase credit and 
interest rate risks, and squeeze profit margins. 

•  The authorities have continued to implement their structural reform program but faster progress 
is needed. The government is taking a number of steps to improve the private investment climate and 
reduce  the  high  cost  of  doing  business,  including  by  streamlining  procedures  for  new  investment. 
Recent prosecution of a number of high level corruption cases, including at state banks, has signaled the 
government’s  commitment  to  improve  governance.  However,  the  operating  agreement  between 
Pertamina and ExxonMobil, which will help boost oil production, is yet to be completed. Progress has 
also been limited in the areas of  revenue administration, labor market reforms,  and judicial and legal 
systems.  

Challenges Ahead 

 

•  Recent events illustrate that vulnerabilities remain, and appropriate and timely policies will be critical 
to  maintaining  macroeconomic  stability  and  achieve  the  economic  objectives  of  high  growth  and 
reduced  unemployment  and  poverty.  The  immediate  policy  priority  for  the  authorities  is  maintaining 
market  confidence  through  careful  monitoring  of  inflation  developments  and  firm  monetary 
restraint  to  contain  the  risk  that  the  recent  fuel  price  increase  lead  to  a  generalized  surge  in 
underlying  inflation,  while  implementing  effectively  the  fuel  price  compensation  scheme  for  the 
poor. These actions will help to ensure that the fall-out from the volatility in financial markets in 
earlier  months  does  not  jeopardize  the  achievement  of  the  authorities’  objectives  of  high  and 
sustained  growth  and  low  unemployment  and  poverty.  Assuming  that  fiscal  and  monetary  policy 
remain  prudent  and  progress  continues  to  be  made  on  structural  reforms  to  improve  the  investment 
climate, we believe that the authorities can achieve their broad economic objectives.

The  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  (NPRS)  has  five  basic  strategies  for  poverty  reduction:  (i)  broadening 
opportunities, (ii) empowering community institutions, (iii) increasing capacity, (iv) providing social protection, and (v) 
promoting  global  partnerships.  The  NPRS  is  to  be  implemented  through  macroeconomic  strategy  and  policies  for 
fulfilling  basic  rights,  for  promoting  gender  justice  and  equality,  and  regional  development.  The  NPRS  considers 
macroeconomic policies as the foundation for reducing poverty through a supportive business environment and broad 
opportunities  for  increasing  the  capability  of  the  poor  through  four  related  objectives  to  (i)  create  macroeconomic 
stability,  (ii)  promote  economic  growth,  (iii)  increase  opportunities  for  employment  and  entrepreneurship,  and  (iv) 
reduce inequalities between regions. The NPRS considers the willingness of central and local governments to manage 
the  budget  in  an  open,  accountable,  efficient,  and  effective  way—  an  essential  prerequisite  for  implementing  the 
NPRS. It recognizes that partnerships are necessary for implementing the NPRS with the private sector and financial 
and nonfinancial banking Institutions identified as key stakeholders.  
 
The country poverty assessment1 and country poverty partnership agreement2 consider macroeconomic stability as a 
fundamental underpinning to poverty reduction. Under the agreement, ADB has agreed to support the Government to 
promote  macroeconomic  stability  for  inclusive  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  Highest  priority  is  given  to  institutional 
reforms  to  achieve  transparent  and  accountable  institutions.  The  poverty  agreement  also  calls  for  expansion  and 
improvement  of  key  basic  services  such  as  health,  education,  water  supply,  and  sanitation  through  public-private 
partnerships  and  the  need  to  expand  a  system  of  social  protection.  At  the  same  time,  the  poverty  partnership 
agreement notes the tremendous fiscal constraint facing the Government in the medium term and therefore the need 
to make the best use of existing resources.
